diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.details: A chronic autoimmune disease that can cause pericardial effusion, thrombocytopenia, fever, and in some cases, a rash similar to psoriasis.

diagnoses.name: Adult Still's Disease
diagnoses.details: A form of arthritis characterized by fever, rash, and joint pain, which can also lead to acute pericarditis and thrombocytopenia.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatic Fever
diagnoses.details: An inflammatory disease that can develop after a Streptococcus pyogenes infection, potentially causing fever, arthritis, and heart complications including pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Drug-induced Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.details: A lupus-like syndrome that can develop in response to certain medications, characterized by symptoms such as rash, fever, and pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease
diagnoses.details: An autoimmune disorder with features of lupus, scleroderma, and polymyositis, including symptoms like rash, fever, joint pain, and heart complications.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.details: An inflammatory disease affecting multiple organs, potentially leading to skin manifestations similar to psoriasis, fever, thrombocytopenia, and heart complications including pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Viral Pericarditis
diagnoses.details: Inflammation of the pericardium due to a viral infection, presenting with chest pain, fever, and potentially leading to pericardial effusion.

diagnoses.name: Tuberculosis (TB)
diagnoses.details: A bacterial infection that can lead to pericarditis, fever, and rare skin manifestations. Thrombocytopenia may also appear in disseminated TB.

diagnoses.name: Psoriatic Arthritis
diagnoses.details: An inflammatory joint disease associated with psoriasis, which can also feature symptoms like fever and potentially pericarditis or effusion in severe cases.

diagnoses.name: Familial Mediterranean Fever
diagnoses.details: A genetic disorder characterized by recurrent fevers and peritonitis, which can also manifest with pericarditis and rash.

diagnoses: Schizophrenia (acute psychotic episode triggered by fever or systemic illness)
Rickettsial Diseases (e.g., Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever)

diagnoses.reasoning: Wheezing is a common symptom, and sweats and chest pain can occur during severe asthma attacks. However, asthma typically does not cause sensory neuropathies or osteopenia directly.

Wheezing and chest pain are common symptoms, especially during exacerbations. Sweating can occur during significant effort or exacerbation. COPD doesn't directly cause sensory neuropathies or osteopenia, but chronic illness and steroid use could contribute to osteopenia.

This multisystem inflammatory disease can cause wheezing and chest pain due to lung involvement. Peripheral neuropathy and hypercalcemia-induced osteopenia are possible but less common manifestations.

While primarily known for affecting plasma cells, it can cause osteopenia due to bone involvement. Peripheral neuropathy is a possible symptom due to the disease or its treatment. Chest pain and sweats could also be symptoms. Wheezing is less typical but might occur secondary to anemia or infections.

A chronic autoimmune disease that can present with chest pain due to pleurisy or pericarditis and may cause peripheral neuropathy. Sweats could be a nonspecific symptom. Osteopenia could result from chronic illness and steroid use.
In its late stages, it can cause peripheral neuropathy and sweats. While less common, chest pain and wheezing could occur. Osteopenia is not typically associated with Lyme disease.

While primarily affecting joints, RA can involve the lungs causing wheezing and chest pain. Osteopenia could occur near affected joints or as a systemic feature. Peripheral neuropathy might develop secondary to inflammation or treatment complications.

This metabolic disorder can cause peripheral neuropathy and contribute to osteopenia due to chronic inflammation and possible steroid treatment. While diabetes itself does not cause wheezing or chest pain, associated cardiovascular issues could manifest as chest pain.
Can cause peripheral neuropathy and osteopenia through poor nutrition and anemia. While chest pain and wheezing are less directly associated, they could arise from anemia-related complications.

Can lead to peripheral neuropathy and, potentially, to osteopenia due to altered metabolism. Sweats are less commonly associated, as hypothyroidism more typically causes cold intolerance, but they can occur, particularly during myxedema coma. Wheezing and chest pain are not typical symptoms but could relate indirectly to overall health deterioration.

diagnoses: Vitamin B12 or folate deficiency anemia

diagnoses.name: Chronic Kidney Disease
diagnoses.description: A long-term condition where the kidneys don't work as well as they should. It can affect anyone, but it's more common in people who are black or of south Asian origin.

diagnoses.name: Urticaria (Hives)
diagnoses.description: An outbreak of swollen, pale red bumps or plaques (wheals) on the skin that appear suddenly either as a result of the body's reaction to certain allergens or for unknown reasons. Dermatographism is a physical urticaria triggered by a firm stroke of the skin.

diagnoses.name: Irritable Bowel Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A common disorder that affects the large intestine. Symptoms include cramping, abdominal pain, bloating, gas, and diarrhea or constipation, or both. IBS is a chronic condition that you'll need to manage long term.

diagnoses.name: Interstitial Cystitis
diagnoses.description: A chronic condition causing bladder pressure, bladder pain and sometimes pelvic pain. The condition is a part of a spectrum of diseases known as painful bladder syndrome.

diagnoses.name: Fibromyalgia
diagnoses.description: A long-term condition that causes pain all over the body. People with fibromyalgia may also have dermatographism, chronic kidney disease, and interstitial cystitis, making diagnosis challenging.

diagnoses.name: Depression
diagnoses.description: A common but serious mood disorder. It causes severe symptoms that affect how you feel, think, and handle daily activities, such as sleeping, eating, or working. Irritability is a common symptom of depression.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition in which your thyroid gland doesn't produce enough of certain crucial hormones. Hypothyroidism's symptoms might include fatigue, weight gain, constipation, and irritability.

diagnoses.name: Lupus
diagnoses.description: A systemic autoimmune disease that occurs when your body's immune system attacks your own tissues and organs. Lupus can cause dermatographism and may indirectly affect kidney function, leading to chronic kidney disease.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes
diagnoses.description: A chronic disease that affects how your body turns food into energy. Over time, having too much glucose in your blood can cause health problems, including kidney disease and nerve damage which can contribute to symptoms such as irritability and constipation.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A disease in which the immune system eats away at the protective covering of nerves. MS can lead to a variety of symptoms, including those affecting the bladder and bowel function, which may mimic or coincide with symptoms of interstitial cystitis and constipation.

diagnoses: Reactive Thrombocytosis due to Infection or Inflammation

diagnoses.name: Asthma
diagnoses.description: Asthma is a condition in which your airways narrow and swell and may produce extra mucus. This can make breathing difficult and trigger coughing, wheezing and shortness of breath.

diagnoses.name: Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD)
diagnoses.description: A chronic digestive disease where stomach acid or, occasionally, stomach content, flows back into the esophagus, causing irritation. GERD can lead to symptoms like heartburn, ulcers and difficulty swallowing (dysphagia).

diagnoses.name: Allergic Rhinitis
diagnoses.description: Allergic rhinitis is an allergic reaction that happens when your immune system overreacts to substances that you inhale. It can cause sneezing, itching, runny or blocked nose, and can sometimes lead to ear infections like Otitis externa.

diagnoses.name: Eosinophilic Esophagitis
diagnoses.description: An immune system disease in which a type of white blood cell (eosinophil) builds up in the lining of the tube that connects your mouth to your stomach (esophagus) leading to dysphagia and often food impaction.

diagnoses.name: Peptic Ulcer Disease
diagnoses.description: Open sores that develop on the inside lining of your stomach and the upper portion of your small intestine. The most common symptom is stomach pain. It may also lead to symptoms such as dysphagia if the ulcers are located at the esophageal area.

diagnoses.name: Anxiety Disorder
diagnoses.description: Anxiety disorders can cause rapid heart rate, palpitations, and chest pain. You may also experience excessive worrying, fear, feeling of being overwhelmed, and hyperactivity.

diagnoses.name: Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD)
diagnoses.description: A brain disorder marked by an ongoing pattern of inattention and/or hyperactivity-impulsivity that interferes with functioning or development.

diagnoses.name: Zollinger-Ellison Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare condition in which one or more tumors form in your pancreas or the upper part of your small intestine (duodenum). These tumors, called gastrinomas, secrete large amounts of gastrin, causing your stomach to produce too much acid. This can lead to peptic ulcers.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD)
diagnoses.description: A chronic inflammatory lung disease that causes obstructed airflow from the lungs. Symptoms include breathing difficulty, cough, mucus (sputum) production and wheezing.

diagnoses.name: Laryngopharyngeal Reflux
diagnoses.description: A condition in which acid that is made in the stomach travels up the esophagus (swallowing tube) and gets to the throat. Symptoms include sore throat, hoarseness, and difficulty swallowing (dysphagia).

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses: Vitamin Deficiencies – Certain vitamin deficiencies (like B12, zinc, and others) can lead to dysgeusia and increased susceptibility to infections due to their roles in maintaining oral health and immune function.
Diabetes Mellitus – Diabetes can cause dysgeusia, periodontal disease, increase susceptibility to infections due to altered glucose metabolism and its effects on blood vessels and nerves.
Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD) – GERD can cause dysgeusia due to acid reflux, and chest pain due to esophageal irritation. It might also loosely relate to migratory abdominal pain.

Cardiovascular Diseases – Certain cardiovascular conditions (like angina) can cause chest pain and might indirectly affect oral health through changes in blood flow, potentially exacerbating conditions like periodontal disease.

Rheumatoid Arthritis – It can cause increased susceptibility to infections due to immune system dysfunction, and can be linked to periodontal disease. Migratory abdominal pain could be related to associated gastrointestinal issues.

Sjögren's Syndrome – This autoimmune disorder can cause dysgeusia due to dry mouth, increase susceptibility to oral infections and periodontal disease due to decreased saliva production, and can be associated with chest pain and abdominal issues.

Hepatitis – Certain liver conditions, like hepatitis, can cause dysgeusia, increase susceptibility to infections due to weakened liver function, and cause abdominal pain. Hepatitis is less directly related to chest pain and periodontal disease but can have wide-ranging systemic effects.

HIV/AIDS – HIV/AIDS significantly increases susceptibility to infections, can lead to periodontal disease, and cause a wide array of systemic symptoms including chest pain and abdominal pain due to its impact on the immune system.

Peptic Ulcer Disease – This can cause dysgeusia due to changes in stomach acidity, migratory abdominal pain due to the nature of ulcers, and chest pain if ulcers are present in the upper gastrointestinal tract.

Celiac Disease – Celiac disease can lead to dysgeusia due to nutrient malabsorption, migratory abdominal pain due to inflammation of the small intestine, and increase susceptibility to infections due to malnutrition and compromised immune function.

diagnoses.description: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.rationale: Can cause hypoglycemia and neuropathies; associated with hypertension due to vascular complications.

diagnoses.description: Chronic Kidney Disease
diagnoses.rationale: May cause hypertension, can be associated with neuropathies and electrolyte imbalances leading to leukocytosis.

diagnoses.description: Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD)
diagnoses.rationale: Bronchitis is a primary symptom and can lead to complications requiring steroids, which may then cause leukocytosis.

diagnoses.description: Acute Bronchitis
diagnoses.rationale: Directly explains the presence of bronchitis; can occasionally be associated with leukocytosis.

diagnoses.description: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.rationale: Can explain leukocytosis, sensory neuropathies, and is associated with a higher risk of hypertension.

diagnoses.description: Multiple Myeloma
diagnoses.rationale: Can lead to neuropathies, leukocytosis, and hyperviscosity syndrome which may present with symptoms similar to hypoglycemia.

diagnoses.description: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.rationale: Can present with sensory neuropathies, leukocytosis (as part of an immune response in early infection), and can predispose individuals to infections such as bronchitis.

diagnoses.description: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.rationale: May cause systemic symptoms like leukocytosis, and neuropathies. Pulmonary involvement can mimic bronchitis.

diagnoses.description: Lymphoma
diagnoses.rationale: Can cause leukocytosis, and patients can experience symptoms like weight loss, which might be misinterpreted as hypoglycemia.

diagnoses.description: Vasculitis
diagnoses.rationale: Can cause neuropathies and hypertension; systemic inflammation might lead to leukocytosis.

diagnoses: Conjunctivitis (if the conjunctival injection is related)
Functional gastrointestinal disorders (e.g., Irritable Bowel Syndrome)
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (Crohn's Disease and Ulcerative Colitis)
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS)
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (e.g., Crohn's Disease, Ulcerative Colitis)
Food Allergy or Intolerance (e.g., lactose intolerance)
Functional Gastrointestinal Disorder of unknown origin
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS)

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A chronic illness involving your central nervous system. The immune system attacks myelin, which is the protective layer around your nerve fibers, leading to delayed response or permanent nerve damage.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: A type of migraine that involves visual disturbances and other neurological symptoms (the 'aura') approximately 20 to 60 minutes before the headache begins.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: Occurs when the blood supply to part of your brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients. Brain cells begin to die in minutes.

diagnoses.name: Myasthenia Gravis
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune neuromuscular disease that causes weakness in the skeletal muscles, which are responsible for breathing and moving parts of the body, including the arms and legs.

diagnoses.name: Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS)
diagnoses.description: A group of rare neurological diseases that mainly involve the nerve cells (neurons) responsible for controlling voluntary muscle movement. Voluntary muscles produce movements like chewing, walking, and talking.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: A mass or growth of abnormal cells in your brain or close to your brain. Many different types of brain tumors exist. Some brain tumors are noncancerous (benign), and some brain tumors are cancerous (malignant).

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, a transient ischemic attack is a brief, temporary disruption of blood supply to your brain. It's often a warning sign of a future stroke.

diagnoses.name: Guillain-Barré Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder in which your body's immune system attacks your nerves. Weakness and tingling in your extremities are usually the first symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Multiple System Atrophy (MSA)
diagnoses.description: A rare neurodegenerative disorder that impairs your body's involuntary functions, including blood pressure, heart rate, bladder function, and digestion.

diagnoses.name: Optic Neuritis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation that damages the optic nerve, a bundle of nerve fibers that transmits visual information from your eye to your brain. Pain and temporary vision loss in one eye are common symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.details: A neurological condition that can cause multiple symptoms. It's frequently characterized by intense, debilitating headaches.

diagnoses.name: Vertigo-associated disorders
diagnoses.details: Includes peripheral vertigo conditions like benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV), Meniere's disease, and vestibular neuritis.

diagnoses.name: Brain tumor
diagnoses.details: Any intracranial tumor can cause headaches, nausea, and sometimes vertigo due to increased intracranial pressure or specific tumor locations.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.details: A cerebrovascular accident causing brain damage. Symptoms depend on the area affected but can include headache, dizziness, and problems with balance.

diagnoses.name: Concussion
diagnoses.details: A mild traumatic brain injury that can cause headache, difficulty with concentration, memory, balance, and coordination.

diagnoses.name: Medication overuse headache
diagnoses.details: Headaches resulting from chronic and excessive use of medication to treat headache symptoms, including nausea.

diagnoses.name: Dehydration
diagnoses.details: Severe dehydration can lead to headache, nausea, and dizziness due to reduced blood volume affecting brain function.

diagnoses.name: Viral infections
diagnoses.details: Such as the flu or mononucleosis, can produce headache, nausea, and vertigo-like symptoms, often accompanied by fever.

diagnoses.name: Anemia
diagnoses.details: A decrease in the total amount of red blood cells (RBCs) or hemoglobin in the blood can cause fatigue, headache, and dizziness.

diagnoses.name: Hypoglycemia
diagnoses.details: Low blood sugar can lead to symptoms including headache, dizziness, and nausea, especially in diabetic patients not properly managing their insulin.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A condition where poor blood flow to the brain results in cell death, causing symptoms such as weakness, headache, and aphasia.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a minibar, a temporary blockage of blood flow to the brain, causing similar, but temporary, symptoms to a stroke.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: A type of headache that is often preceded by sensory disturbances known as an aura, can include symptoms like weakness and language disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: Abnormal growth of cells within the brain or the skull vault, which can cause pressure effects including headache, weakness, and aphasia.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis (MS)
diagnoses.description: A disease in which the immune system eats away at the protective covering of nerves, potentially causing weakness, language difficulties, and more.

diagnoses.name: Epilepsy
diagnoses.description: A neurological disorder marked by sudden recurrent episodes of sensory disturbance, loss of consciousness, or convulsions, associated with abnormal electrical activity in the brain. Postictal state can include headache, weakness, and aphasia.

diagnoses.name: Brain Abscess
diagnoses.description: A focal infection in the brain causing swelling, often leading to headache, neurological deficits like weakness, and sometimes language disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Encephalitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the brain, caused by infection or an autoimmune response. Symptoms can include headache, neurological deficits, and problems with speech.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the brain and spinal cord membranes, typically caused by an infection. The inflammation can lead to symptoms like headache, weakness, and in severe cases, difficulties with language.

diagnoses.name: Hemorrhagic Stroke
diagnoses.description: Occurs when a blood vessel in the brain bursts, leaking blood into the surrounding tissue and causing symptoms such as headache, weakness, and aphasia due to the pressure of the blood on the brain.

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.details: A neurological condition that can cause multiple symptoms. It's frequently characterized by intense, debilitating headaches.

diagnoses.name: Tension headache
diagnoses.details: A common type of headache characterized by pain around the head, scalp, or neck, often associated with muscle tightness.

diagnoses.name: Cluster headache
diagnoses.details: A series of relatively short but extremely painful headaches every day for weeks or months at a time.

diagnoses.name: Brain tumor
diagnoses.details: A mass or growth of abnormal cells in your brain. Its symptoms depend on the size, type, and location.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.details: A medical condition that occurs when the blood supply to part of the brain is cut off. Symptoms include numbness, confusion, and difficulty speaking.

diagnoses.name: Multiple sclerosis (MS)
diagnoses.details: A potentially disabling disease of the brain and spinal cord (central nervous system). It can cause numbness, tingling, mood swings, memory problems, and more.

diagnoses.name: Dehydration
diagnoses.details: A condition that occurs when you use or lose more fluid than you take in, and your body doesn't have enough water and other fluids to carry out its normal functions.

diagnoses.name: Vertebral artery dissection
diagnoses.details: A tear in the lining of a vertebral artery, which can lead to stroke. Symptoms can include headache, neck pain, and numbness.

diagnoses.name: Transient ischemic attack (TIA)
diagnoses.details: Often called a mini-stroke, a transient ischemic attack is a brief period of symptoms similar to those of a stroke.

diagnoses.name: Medication overuse headache
diagnoses.details: Headaches caused by overuse of medication to treat headache symptoms. Also known as rebound headaches.

diagnoses: Primary angiitis of the central nervous system
HELLP Syndrome (Hemolysis, Elevated Liver enzymes, Low Platelet count)
Evan's Syndrome (Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemia combined with Immune Thrombocytopenic Purpura)
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) syndrome
Viral infection (e.g., parvovirus B19, Epstein-Barr virus)
Viral Infections (e.g., Parvovirus B19, Epstein-Barr virus)
Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (formerly known as Wegener's granulomatosis)
Hepatitis B and C Related Cryoglobulinemia
